title: Data Analytics Blog
text: This blog is for weekly assignments

title: Notes for class
text:
Learn more about push and pull about git
make a change, commit and push the change.
Make changes to you to ur file.
Render your websites.
Commit the changes.
Push to the origin
Rstudio IDE is a great resource.
A reproducible report allows others to understand and check your work.
never install a package inside of the script
there is another easy way to use a function. You can simply use package::function()
Whenever you put comma in a function, it means you are giving different arguments to it. For example, mean(x=1,2,3,4,5) means more than one argument

title: Week 3 qmd skills
text:
Be able to make a new .qmd document
Be able to render a .qmd document
Be able to insert simple markdown plain text (headers, lists, paragraphs), and render the document.

#This is a first level header ##This is a second level header 4. Be aware of resources to help you learn more about markdown options. 5. Be able to insert an R code chunk, and show the output in the rendered document. - macro for quick insert 6. Running R code chunks in a qmd - pressing play - copy/paste into console - highlight then command-enter (mac) - precedence issues (first to last) 7. Be aware of R code chunk options, and how to use eval, messages, error, warning, and echo. 8. Be able to set code chunk options per chunk, and/or for the whole document. Understand rules for precedence (which options will apply if both are set.) 9. Write inline r code. 10. Explain how the rendering environment is different from the Rstudio environment. 11. Be aware of more advanced quarto options for html documents, and try some of the options.

title: Notes for class
text:
Learn more about push and pull about git
make a change, commit and push the change.
Make changes to you to ur file.
Render your websites.
Commit the changes.
Push to the origin
Rstudio IDE is a great resource.
A reproducible report allows others to understand and check your work.
never install a package inside of the script
there is another easy way to use a function. You can simply use package::function()
Whenever you put comma in a function, it means you are giving different arguments to it. For example, mean(x=1,2,3,4,5) means more than one argument
c() function has many uses
Assigning things to our objects “<-”
as.numeric turns strings into numbers

title: week 3 qmd skill check
text:
Be able to make a new .qmd document

Yes I copied my welcome post, and then renamed it

Be able to render a .qmd document I was able yo do that
Be able to insert simple markdown plain text (headers, lists, paragraphs), and render the document. #This is a Header strikethrough this is bold text https://quarto.org


unordered list

sub-item 1
sub-item 2

sub-sub-item 1




Be aware of resources to help you learn more about markdown options. Yes
Be able to insert an R code chunk, and show the output in the rendered document.


macro for quick insert command-option-i


a<- c(4,6,7,7)
mean(a)

[1] 6



Running R code chunks in a qmd


pressing play-Yes
copy/paste into console -Done
highlight then command-enter (mac)
precedence issues (first to last)


Be aware of R code chunk options, and how to use eval, messages, error, warning, and echo.
Be able to set code chunk options per chunk, and/or for the whole document. Understand rules for precedence (which options will apply if both are set.)
Write inline r code.
Explain how the rendering environment is different from the Rstudio environment.
Be aware of more advanced quarto options for html documents, and try some of the options.
